pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:2.1: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:3.1: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:4.1: 4. The fourth training rule on offenses entailing acknowledgment
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:5.3: At one time the Buddha was staying in the Sakyan country at Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:5.4: At that time the slaves of the Sakyans were rebelling.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:5.5: Sakyan women wished to prepare a meal for monks in wilderness dwellings,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:5.6: but the slaves heard about this
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:5.9: When the Sakyan women took various kinds of nice food and set out for a wilderness dwelling,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:5.10: the slaves emerged, and they robbed and raped those Sakyan women.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:5.11: The Sakyan men then came out and got hold of those thieves together with their loot. They then complained and criticized the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:5.12: “How can they not announce that there are bandits staying in the monastery?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:6.1: The monks heard the complaints of the Sakyans
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:6.3: Soon afterwards the Master gave a teaching and addressed the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:6.4: “Well then, monks, I will lay down a training rule for the following ten reasons: for the well-being of the Order, for the comfort of the Order, for the restraint of bad people, for the ease of well-behaved monks, for the restraint of corruptions in the present life, for avoiding corruptions in future lives, to give rise to confidence in those without it, to increase the confidence of those who have it, for the continuation of the true Teaching, and for supporting the training.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:6.5: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:7.2: ‘There are wilderness dwellings that are considered risky and dangerous. If a monk, without first making an announcement about those dwellings, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it inside that monastery, he must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:7.3: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:8.1: In this way the Master laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:9.2: Soon afterwards a monk in a wilderness dwelling was sick.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:9.3: People took staple and non-staple food and went to that wilderness dwelling,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:9.4: and they invited that monk to eat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:9.7: But knowing that the Master had prohibited the eating of staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it at a wilderness dwelling, and being afraid of wrongdoing, he did not accept it. And not being able to walk for alms, he missed his meal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:10.1: That monk then told the monks what had happened,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:10.2: and they in turn told the Master.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:10.3: Soon afterwards the Master gave a teaching and addressed the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:10.4: “Monks, I allow a sick monk, without first making an announcement, to eat staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it at a wilderness dwelling.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:10.5: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:11.1: ‘There are wilderness dwellings that are considered risky and dangerous. If a monk who is not sick, without first making an announcement about those dwellings, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it inside that monastery, he must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:11.2: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:12.2: it is called a wilderness dwelling if it is at least one kilometer away from any inhabited area.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:13.2: in the monastery, or in the vicinity of the monastery, thieves have been seen camped, eating, standing, seated, or lying down.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:14.2: in the monastery, or in the vicinity of the monastery, thieves have been seen injuring, robbing, or beating people.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:15.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a complete Order through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:17.2: if it is announced to any of one’s five co-monastics, this is called “without making an announcement.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:17.3: If it is announced about anything apart from a monastery and its vicinity, this is called “without making an announcement.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:18.2: if a woman or a man who comes to the monastery or the vicinity of the monastery says, “Venerable, they’ll bring so-and-so’s staple or non-staple food,” then, if it is risky, this should be declared, and if it is dangerous, this should be declared.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:18.3: If the person says, “Let it be, Venerable, it will be brought,” then the bandits are to be told, “People are coming here; go away.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:18.4: When an announcement has been made in regard to rice-porridge, and accompanying food is brought, this is called “announced.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:18.5: When an announcement has been made in regard to a meal, and accompanying food is brought, this is called “announced.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:18.6: When an announcement has been made in regard to non-staple food, and accompanying food is brought, this is called “announced.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:18.7: When an announcement has been made in regard to a particular family, then when any person from that family brings staple or non-staple food, this is called “announced.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:18.8: When an announcement has been made in regard to a particular village, then when any person from that village brings staple or non-staple food, this is called “announced.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:18.9: When an announcement has been made in regard to a particular association, then when any person from that association brings staple or non-staple food, this is called “announced.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:19.2: apart from the five staple foods, the post-midday tonics, the seven-day tonics, and the lifetime tonics—the rest is called “non-staple food.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:20.2: there are five kinds of staple food: cooked grain, porridge, flour, fish, and meat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:21.2: if the monastery is enclosed, then within the enclosure.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:21.3: If the monastery is not enclosed, then in the vicinity.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:22.2: who is able to walk for alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:23.2: who is not able to walk for alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:24.1: If it has not been announced and he is not sick, and he receives staple and non-staple food with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:24.2: For every mouthful, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:25.1: If it has not been announced, and he does not perceive it as announced, and he, when not sick, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it inside that monastery, then he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:25.2: If it has not been announced, but he is unsure of it, and he, when not sick, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it inside that monastery, then he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:25.3: If it has not been announced, but he perceives it as announced, and he, when not sick, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it inside that monastery, then he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:26.1: If he receives post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics for the purpose of food, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:26.2: For every mouthful, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:26.3: If it has been announced, but he does not perceive it as announced, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:26.4: If it has been announced, but he is unsure if it has, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:26.5: If it has been announced, and he perceives it as announced, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:27.4: if he eats the leftovers from where there has been an announcement or from one who is sick;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:27.5: if he receives the food outside the monastery and then eats it inside;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:27.6: if he eats a root, bark, a leaf, a flower, or a fruit grown in the monastery;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:27.7: if he uses post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics when there is a reason;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:27.9: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:28.1: The fourth training rule entailing acknowledgment is finished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:29.1: “Venerables, the four rules on offenses entailing acknowledgment have been recited.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:29.2: In regard to this I ask you,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:29.8: You are pure in this and therefore silent. I will remember it thus.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd4:30.1: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment is finished.
